title-group.article-title: A low-order canyon model to estimate the influence of canyon shape on the maximum urban heat island effect

abstract.p: A simple mathematical model of an urban canyon is developed. The canyon model consists of horizontal and vertical slabs providing thermal storage for heat and absorption of and shielding from solar radiation and long wave radiation to the sky. The model is compared to a horizontal slab in a rural location to examine the effect of the canyon shape. The results show the same trend as measurements by others, with increasing urban heat island (UHI) effect with increasing canyon aspect ratio. The model is then used to determine the maximum UHI effect by producing a simple algebraic equation. This compares well with measurements in Greater Manchester of canyon and rural temperatures although some empirical adjustments are required. The strong influence of cloud cover is shown by the model and measurements as are the canyon shape and the ground temperature.

Practical applications: The model is simple and developed in terms applicable to building services engineers, using ventilation rates through the canyon. It also does not require more than the standard weather data available in a CIBSE Test Reference Year or a Design Summer Year. From this model, the UHI effect can be developed to adjust the data from a rural site to that of an urban and city centre site. This is useful for building designers to take account of the UHI effect which they cannot do at present. This would also be useful for UKCP09 data which have been released.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: Designers have designed and adapted buildings traditionally using historic weather data to assess the design extremes1 for assessing comfort and plant size. Such data have typically come from airports where UK MetO weather stations are sited or rural areas. However, this does not fully represent the urban or city climate where most new buildings are sited. Cities and urban areas modify the climate to an extent creating a microclimate. This is due to a number of complex factors such as the loss of cooling vegetative surfaces, increased anthropogenic activity and heat storage in the built environment of the city, urban area as well as the ‘canyon’ effect. It is the latter that this article examines. However, it is all of these factors contribute to an ‘Urban Heat Island’ (UHI) effect2 which can lead to temperature differences of up to 7°C between the centres of large conurbations in the UK and their surrounding rural areas.3,4

This temperature difference, or UHI effect, is at its most pronounced during the night time when the release of stored heat, and the containment of outgoing long wave radiation leads to elevated urban temperatures5 (the UHI effect).

As a consequence, the inhabitants of cities have difficulty in finding respite from high summer temperatures, and this threat to human comfort and well-being poses a significant challenge for designers and urban planners.6 This problem will increase under future climate change scenarios and projections of urbanisation. The urban population of Europe is predicted to increase from 73% of the total population in 2000 to 80% in 20307 and temperature increases of 0.1–0.5°C per decade are expected across the UK and Europe during the 21st century.8,9 Although the summer UHI effect is a serious cause for concern, the winter UHI effect helps maintain urban areas warmer in winter periods although better insulation and more efficient buildings are preferable ways to keep urban occupants warmer.

The study in this article has been developed in the EPSRC COPSE10 proposal, which is examining the use of the UKCP0911 data for building designers. The aspect examining the UHI effect is based on the EPSRC SCORCHIO12 project which in turn followed on from the EPSRC ASCCUE13 project. This latter project used an urban morphology typology combined with the Tso14,15 energy balance model to assess the UHI effect over the Greater Manchester area. SCORCHIO has developed this further with an updated climate change scenario weather model, including an anthropogenic heat forcing element, more detailed urban typologies and extensive air and radiant temperature measurements to develop a tool to examine climate change adaptation strategies in urban areas. However, the Tso energy balance model does not consider the canyon shape, virtually treating all buildings as crushed masses of concrete and fabric to represent the heat storage capacity of the building.

However, the actual canyon shape is important in solar shielding, and reducing long wave losses to the ‘cold’ night sky. There are plenty of UHI and canyon models, for instance Oke’s scaled-physical model16 of 1981, Johnson et al.’s SHIM model17,18 of 1991, Mills Model of 199319 and later models such as Erell’s and Williamson’s.20 ENVI-met21 can be used to model the microclimate in three dimensions in an urban area, including a street canyon to a resolution of 0.5 m. More detailed canyon models with 10 layers for the canyon surfaces and detailed radiation exchanges are available.22 JULES23 (Joint UK Land Environment Simulator), is a land surface model that can be used for the rural and urban microclimate based on the MetO’s Met Office Surface Exchange System (MOSES). JULES can also model photosynthesis, soil and water fluxes, snow melt, etc.

However, these are fairly complex models and a number rely on detailed meteorological data not available to a building designer. Also, the terminology and detail of many such models, which are effectively micro-meteorological models, are not readily accessible for a building designer. The model developed in this article is in terms of building heat transfers available in CIBSE publications and using weather parameters in Test Reference Years and Design Summer Years.24 For determining the maximum UHI effect, this model is used to compare a rural slab with a canyon, also made of similar slabs so that the shape canyon effect can be analysed.

sec.title: 2 Basic slab model
sec.p:
Consider a canyon as per Figure 1 with width W [m], height H [m] and length L [m]. The elements of the canyon are x [m] thick. To estimate the influence of the canyon shape, this can be compared with a slab component of width W and length L with thickness x but without the side components making the canyon. Figure 1
Heat exchanges for a slab

sec.title: 2.1 Energy exchanges for the slab
sec.p: Consider the energy exchanges for the slab upper surface, initially, shown in Figure 1. Only sensible heat transfer is considered as no vegetation or water is considered at the slab or the canyon. Hence, the energy exchanges are: (1)αQs=Qslab+Ql+Qas where Qs is the horizontal global solar irradiance [W] = αAqs where A is the area [m2] and qs the horizontal global solar irradiance flux [W m−2]. Qslab is the heat into the slab [W], Ql the net long wave irradiance emitted from the slab surface [W], Qas the convective, turbulent flux heat transfer and advective heat loss to the air from the slab [W] and α absorption of solar irradiance into the slab.
Qs can be obtained on an hourly basis from the weather data provided by CIBSE.24

sec.title: 2.1.1 Conduction
sec.p: The conduction in the slab is given by the one-dimensional form of Fourier’s equation: (2)Qslab=A(tso-ts)x/2kQslab=A(tso-ts)x/2k where tso is the outside (upper) surface temperature slab [°C], ts the temperature of the middle of the slab [°C], x the thickness of the slab [m], k the conductivity of the slab [W m−1 K−1] and A the surface area of the slab [m2].
Given that the slab is width W [m] and length L [m], Equation (2) becomes: (3)Qslab=2kLW(tso-ts)x

The heat into the slab is stored in the mass of the slab (in the first-order model of the slab at the mid-point node, with temperature ts) and some, Qe [W], is lost to the earth, giving: (4)Qslab=Qe+ρLWxCpdtsdT where ρ is the density of the slab [kg m−3], Cp the specific heat capacity of the slab [J m−3 K−1] and T the time [s].
The flow to the earth is related to the mid-slab temperature, ts, and the earth temperature, te [°C]: (5)Qe=2kLW(ts-te)x

The earth temperature varies throughout the year depending on the depth at which it is measured. For a day in the summer (July and August) the earth temperature at 0.5 m depth is 6.5 K25 above the year average for Manchester of 10°C26 giving an earth temperature of 16.5°C. In this simple model, the earth temperature under the concrete slab is assumed constant although the actual earth surface temperature will vary considerably during the day.27

sec.title: 2.1.2 Convection, turbulent heat flux transfer and advection
sec.p: When the slab warms up by radiation during the day the air near the slab warms by conduction. Being hotter than the air above it (the air temperature steadily reduces with height with a dry adiabatic lapse rate of about28 9.8 K km−1), the warm air rises as a turbulent thermal. However, at night the slab radiates in the long wave and a stable boundary layer of air develops,26 which is warmer than the slab; hence, convective heat flow stops. The maximum UHI effect typically occurs during the night,1,5 which has been confirmed by measurements in a number of sites in Greater Manchester. Hence, the conduction and turbulent heat transfer and advection term, Qas, is considered as insignificant.

sec.title: 2.1.3 Solar and long wave irradiation
sec.p: Weather data give the horizontal global irradiance each hour, qs, [W m−2] to produce the solar power input to the slab: (6)Qs=qsLW

The net long wave irradiation from the slab is complicated as it is necessitates determining the sky temperature added to which there is downward long wave radiation from the atmosphere which is difficult to calculate. The current CIBSE Guide J26 gives details of the sky temperature used to determine the sol–air temperature. However, a simpler equation for a horizontal surface, suitable for the simple model is given by:29 (7a)Ql=LW(93-79C) where Ql is the long wave radiation losses from the slab [W] and C the cloud cover (0 ≤ C ≤ 1).
An alternative net long wave irradiation equation is:28 (7b)Ql=LW(98.5[1-C])

sec.title: 2.1.4 Slab differential equation
sec.p: Substituting Equations (3)–(5) and (7a) into Equation (1): αQs=Qslab+Ql+Qas gives the overall, slab differential equation: αqs=2k(ts-te)x+ρxCpdtsdT+(93-79C)
Rearranging gives: (8)[xk]{αqs-(93-79C)}-2(ts-te)=τdtsdT where (9)τ=ρx2Cpk where τ being the time constant of the slab [s].
This becomes: (10)β-ts=τ2dtsdT where (11)β=[x2k]{αqs-(93-79C)}+te
To which the solution is: (12)T2-T1=τ2ln[β-ts1β-ts2] or (13)ts2-ts1=(β-ts1)[1-exp(-2(T2-T1)τ)]

sec.title: 3 Basic canyon model
sec.p:
Figure 2 shows the canyon. The opening at the top has the same area as the slab, and so the canyon receives the same solar irradiance as the slab. To simplify matters for comparison with the slab and to examine the effect of the canyon shape, the canyon is considered as three slabs, two vertical and one horizontal. The two vertical slabs represent buildings with the ‘external surface’ facing into the canyon and the interior surface of the buildings being the ‘outside’ surfaces in Figure 2. Roofs, not shown in Figure 2, shield the outer sides of the vertical slabs. Figure 2
A canyon

sec.title: 3.1 Energy exchanges for the canyon
sec.p: The energy exchange processes, conduction, irradiation and convection are the same as for the slab except the geometry that is different.

sec.title: 3.1.1 Conduction
sec.p: The conduction of the canyon is similar to that of the slab. However, the edge effects, where the vertical canyon sides join the slab, are ignored. Hence, the heat conduction at the canyon’s inside surface, Qcanyon, is: (14)Qcanyon=2kL(2H+W)(tco-tc)x where (Figure 2), Tco is the outside (inside) surface temperature of the canyon [°C] and Tc the temperature of the middle of the canyon slabs [°C].

The heat into the canyon is stored in the mass of the canyon (in the first-order model of the canyon at the mid-point node, with temperature tc). There is a heat flow from the canyon slabs, Qcie [W], to (or from) the interiors of the buildings and to the earth under the bottom, base slab giving: (15)Qcanyon=Qcie+ρL(2H+W)xCpdtcdT where the density and specific heat capacity are the same as for the slab (to compare just the shape factor effect of the canyon).
The flow to the canyon building interiors and earth is related to the mid-canyon temperature, tc, and the average canyon building interior and earth temperature, tcie: (16)Qcie=2kL(2H+W)(tc-tcie)x

The canyon building interior temperature, tci, and earth temperature, te, are used to calculate the area weighted ‘outer’ canyon surface temperature, tcie. To keep the model simple, the building interior temperature, tci, is assumed to be constant. The area weighted ‘outer’ material temperature, tcie, is given by: (17)tcie=2LHtci+WLte2HL+WL=2Htci+Wte2H+W

sec.title: 3.1.2 Convection, turbulent flux heat transfer and advection
sec.p: There is convective heat exchange between the air within the canyon and the inside canyon surface, Qac [W]: (18)Qac=L(2H+W)(tco-tca)Rconv where tca is the air temperature in the canyon and Rconv the convective surface heat transfer coefficient [m2 K W−1] = 14+4v.
This equation is not to be used below 1 m s−1.
L(2H + W) is the canyon inside surface area [m2].

Once the air inside the canyon has been heated or cooled then, in building services terms, assuming a ‘stirred tank’ approach (where all the air in the volume, V, is mixed and at a uniform temperature, tca) as per a room ventilation: (19)qAC=(1/3)(NCC+NWCCd)V(tca-tao) where V is the volume of the canyon [m3] = LWH, Ncc the air change rate in the canyon due to natural convection [h−1], Nwc the air change rate in the canyon due to advection (wind) [h−1], tao the external air temperature [°C], Cd the discharge coefficient, which for a sharp-edged opening, is 0.6 [dimensionless] and 1/3 the ratio due to air properties30 [W h m−3 K−1].

Equation (18) can be combined with Equation (19) to produce: (20)Qac=[L(2H+W)V(NWCCd+NCC)Rconv(NWCCd+NCC)V+3L(2H+W)] ×(tco-tao)Qac=ϕca(tco-tao) where (21)ϕca=[L(2H+W)V(NWCCd+NCC)Rconv(NWCCd+NCC)V+3L(2H+W)]

Canyons are often in highly urban, city centre areas where the wind velocity is significantly reduced compared to the open rural terrain:31 (22)vz=vmkza where vz is wind speed [m s−1] at height z [m], vm the reference, measured wind speed in open country usually at a height of 10 m, k, a the constants dependent on the terrain.

The turbulence in the canyon region makes determination of the exact wind speed and direction difficult to determine and canyon measurements are difficult to arrange. Also, there are convective currents in the canyon, which again are difficult to measure. However, these will not be considered as the maximum UHI effect will only be considered by this model. The maximum UHI effect occurs at night when the advective wind speed is very low and the upward convective currents are significantly reduced as the local air temperature is above the surface temperature.29

sec.title: 3.1.3 Solar and long wave irradiation
sec.p:

However, for this simple model, the long wave radiation from the canyon is assumed to be proportional to area of the canyon opening, and the emissivity is the same as for the slab.

sec.title: 3.1.4 Canyon differential equation
sec.p: If the slab and canyon thicknesses and the densities are the same (which are here assumed for analysing the canyon shape on UHI), then the canyon and the slab have the same time constant giving: (23)[x2kL(2H+W)](Qsabc-Qlc-ϕca(tco-tao)) =(tc-tcie)+(τ2)dtcdT
This can be solved similar to Equation (8).

sec.title: 4 Canyon influence on UHI effect
sec.p: The UHI effect is often considered as the difference between the rural and the canyon air temperatures (UHIair) although the difference between the relevant surface temperatures (UHIsurf) is also an important effect. The UHI effect is often greatest just before sunrise.

sec.title: 4.1 Maximum UHI effect
sec.p: To examine the effect of the canyon shape on the UHI, the difference between the slab in a rural location and the canyon in a city situation is considered but the canyon has no external influences. At the minimum temperature for both the slab and the canyon, the differential term will tend to zero if not actually achieving it. Also, the solar irradiance will be zero. Hence, Equation (23) becomes: [x2kL(2H+W)][-Qlc-ϕca(tco-tao)] -(tc-tcie)=0
This is a steady state condition. Hence, 2(tc-tcie)=(tco-tcie) Hence, (24)[xkL(2H+W)][-Qlc-ϕca(tco-tao)]+tcie=tco
Likewise, for the slab from Equation (8): [xk]{-(93-79C)-ϕsa(tso-tao)}-2(ts-te)=0
In the steady state for the slab: 2(ts-te)=(tso-te) So that: (25)[xk]{-(93-79C)-ϕsa(tso-tao)}+te=tso

The UHI is greatest when the wind speed is small (typically under antecyclonic conditions; a clear sky (C = 0) and zero wind speed). Hence, Nws and Nwc are zero. At night time with a clear sky, when the UHI effect is greatest, the boundary layer of the atmosphere becomes stable and the temperature profile of the air is such that the surface is colder than the air above it to a height of almost 0.7 km.5 Hence, the convection is non existent for the slab and much reduced for the canyon. So, for this simple model, Ncs = 0 and Ncc = 0. Under these overall conditions (clear sky, zero advection and zero convection), the air temperatures are assumed to be effectively equal to the mean surface temperatures, which are found in practice.33 Hence, the UHI effect, related to the surface temperatures is Equation (24) minus Equation (25): tco-tso=[xkL(2H+W)][-Qlc] +tcie-te-[xk][-93]

Assuming that the long wave losses from the inside walls and floor of the canyon (via the open horizontal top, of area, WL) is similar to that from the slab, then tco-tso=[xk(2H+W)][-93W] +tcie-te-[xk][-93]
Rearranging gives: (26)tco-tso=[xk][W(2H+W)-1][-93]+tcie-te=[xk][2H(2H+W)][93]+tcie-te
Substituting in Equation (17): (27)tco-tso=[xk][2H(2H+W)][93]+2Htci+Wte2H+W-tetco-tso=[xk][2H(2H+W)][93]+2Htci-2Hte2H+Wtco-tso=[2H(2H+W)][93[xk]+tci-te]

Figure 3 shows the UHI effect from Equation (27). The values of ti, te and tci are derived for Manchester for summer (July and August) conditions. The Manchester mean earth temperature, as discussed before, is 16.5°C and the ti (the inside temperature of the buildings constituting the canyon) is 21°C. Figure 3
Canyon aspect ratio (height/width) influence on UHI effect: k = 1.13 W m−1 K−1, x = 0.1 m, L = 100 m, W = 10 m, tci = 21°C, and te = 16.5°C

Figure 3 shows that as the canyon aspect factor (H/W) increases, the UHI effect also increases. The increase is very rapid at low aspect factors indicating that in fact shallow canyons, representative of small urban housing, have a significant affect, whereas as the canyons get deeper and larger, the effect is less. This trend has previously been observed by Oke5 from measurements of cities around the world. Oke has derived an empirical relationship from the measurements giving the UHI temperature difference (between the rural and urban areas) as: (28)7.54+3.97ln(HW)

This has been used to compare Oke’s results with Equation (27). The root mean error squared between Oke’s empirical equation and Equation (27) is 1.3 K, indicating a reasonable agreement. However, Oke’s equation does go negative at small aspect factors (0.15), despite his measurements being all positive. Equation (27) does not go negative.

sec.title: 5 Canyon model and measurements
sec.p: Equation (27) can be used to model the maximum temperatures in a canyon in Manchester with a rural measurement in Woodford. The canyon temperatures were measured by a data logger in a radiation shield placed on a lamppost 4 m above the pavement.34 The rural Woodford site was the MetO site for Manchester, located about 20 km from the city centre.

The canyon dimensions (height and width) were determined by measuring the width of the road and pavement using an infra red measuring ‘tape’. Sky view pictures were then taken with a camera with a fish eye lens. From the pictures, the sky view factors (SVFs) were determined by Grimmond’s method,35 checked by Chapman’s algorithm,36 written in matlab code. The canyons were not exact rectangular canyons of uniform height. However, the pictures were taken near the temperature loggers and the average canyon height determined here. The SVF is the ratio of the solid angle of the visible sky from the canyon divided by the solid angle of the sky visible in an unobstructed open area (2π). The SVF was determined numerically by the authors for a range of canyon sizes suitable for the Greater Manchester canyons studied. For reasonably long canyons the SVF, as measured from the centre of the canyon, closely approaches Oke’s value:27 (29)SVF=cos{tan-1(2HW)}
Equation (27), when recast in terms of the SVF instead of H and W, gives: (30)tco-tso={tan(cos-1[SVF])1+tan(cos-1[SVF])} ×[93(xk)+tci-te]

The trigonometric term (tan/(1 + tan)) is almost linear as Figure 4 shows. As the term in square brackets is a constant, then the maximum UHI effect (tco − tso) is a linear function of SVF. The trigonometric term does turn down to zero when the SVF approaches 1 (no canyon) but the straight line fit has a good correlation (r2 value of 0.9493, significant to the 0.1% level). Figure 4
The trigonometric term in the maximum UHI effect equation

Figure 5 shows the model output compared to measured data from nine canyons in the centre of Manchester for summer. The values are the average of the UHI measurements from a number of calm, clear nights (100 h over 36 nights with standard deviation of 1.12 K). The r2 value is 0.51 (t = 2.7, significant at the 2.5% level). The model fitted best when [93(xk)+tci-te] had a value of 7.98. For the canyon model of concrete blocks, this implies a low value of x as the conductivity (k) is typically 1.13. The best fit line for the measured data is: (31)UHI effect max=6.43-2.12SVF Figure 5
Model vs canyon measurements in Manchester City centre in the summer

This equation gives a maximum UHI effect of 6.43°C in good agreement with the results in Figure 5. However, the minimum value of the UHI maximum effect is 4.31°C (when SVF = 1). The model would indicate a zero value as it would correspond to the rural slab to which, effectively the canyon is close. But in practice, the urban and suburban sprawl of Greater Manchester is between the city centre canyons and the rural measuring station. This urban and suburban sprawl contributes a significant amount to the UHI effect. Indeed, many of these areas have small canyons themselves. These will be discussed in a future paper.

sec.title: 6 Winter maximum UHI effect
sec.p: Figure 6 shows a number of measurements of the UHI intensity (effect) in Greater Manchester. The night-time values are larger than the daytime values and the larger values more frequent at night. Also, there are a small number of winter night-time values with values above 8°C, higher than the summer night-time values which do not extend beyond 8°C. However, the frequencies of the large winter UHI maxima are less frequent than the summer night-time values. Although the daytime values are generally lower than the night-time values, there are some infrequent, high UHI effect values during the daytime. The shape of the distributions in Figure 6 needs to be considered when the means and standard deviations, shown in Table 1, are examined. The means show the UHI effect to be greater during the night and during the summer.

Figure 7 for the winter shows a good relationship for the nine canyons with the model. As with the summer measurements of the maximum UHI effect are for clear calm nights (140 h over 45 nights with standard deviation of 1.88 K). The model fits the measurements with an r2 value of 0.51 and t of 2.70 (significant to 2.5%). The model fitted best when [93(xk)+tci-te] had a value of 4.82. (32)UHI effect max=4.0-1.68SVF Figure 6
Summer and winter measurements of the UHI intensity in Greater Manchester for all weather conditions in 2010 Figure 7
Model vs canyon measurements in Manchester City centre in the winter
This equation is similar to the summer equation in that when the canyon ‘disappears’ (SVF = 0); then, the UHI effect does not disappear. This again is due to the urban and suburban sprawl.

sec.title: 7 Spring and autumn UHI
sec.p: The spring and autumn UHI effect values are also straight lines, for autumn: (33)UHI effect max=6.35-2.65SVF

The model fits the measurements with an r2 value of 0.51 and t of 2.70 (significant to 2.5%). The model fitted best when [93(xk)+tci-te] had a value of 7.57. For spring: (34)UHI effect max=6.45-2.28SVF
The model fits the measurements with an r2 value of 0.41 and t of 2.21 (significant to 5%). The model fitted best when [93(xk)+tci-te] had a value of 7.94.
Spring and autumn have similar relationships to SVF as the summer and with similar values of [93(xk)+tci-te].

sec.title: 8 The influence of cloud cover
sec.p: If cloud cover is included in the UHI equation, Equation (27): (27)tco-tso=[2H(2H+W)][(93-73C)[xk]+tci-te]

Figure 8 shows Equation (27) for the Manchester canyon data and different values of cloud cover, C. As the cloud cover increases, the maximum UHI effect (at night with calm wind-free conditions) reduces from 8.5°C (at C = 0, H/W = 4) to 2.2°C (at C = 1.0, H/W = 4). This is logical as the surfaces are less exposed to the low radiant sky temperature as the cloud cover increases. Figure 8
The effect of cloud cover on the maximum UHI effect

sec.title: 9 Conclusion
sec.p: From the simple model described above, the maximum UHI effect is reasonably accurate for Oke’s general data and for extensive measurements in Greater Manchester. A simple algebraic term for the maximum UHI effect is derived. It shows that the existence of a canyon is important factor for the UHI with the maximum UHI effect rapidly increasing at low canyon aspect ratios. For the higher canyon aspect ratios the rate of change is less. However, the measurements of the UHI effect for the canyons in Manchester City centre do not tend to zero if the SVF tended to 1 (the canyon disappears). This shows that the influence of the urban and suburban sprawl around the city contributes a significant amount more than the canyon itself to the UHI. The model, which reasonably fits the measurements for the city centre canyons does, however, tend to zero as it is simply compared to the rural slab, without any urban or suburban area in between.

The influence of cloud cover is also a major influence on the maximum UHI effect. High wind speed is found by measurements in Greater Manchester and other studies to greatly reduce the UHI effect but this has not been modelled in any detail as the maximum UHI effect has been investigated.

It should be noted that the model uses simple concrete slabs for the canyon and rural site without considering complex facades and geometries. Also, the slabs are of equal thicknesses making the time constants equal. Often there is a time lag between the canyon temperatures and the rural sites but this will not significantly reduce the UHI effect modelled.
